text: Is feeding to sleep a bad habit?
I feed my 2. Month old to sleep. Babies need comfort 🤷🏼‍♀️ I have tried letting her self sooth and she hasn’t picked up on it yet and that’s totally okay

My son is only 3 months. I feed him to sleep every time. He naps for up to 2 hours, and sleeps through the night. He’s learned to self soothe by sticking on his thumb when his bink falls out of his mouth.

Definitely not a bad habit. Babies need comfort from their caregivers to feel safe and secure to fall asleep. Why withhold that comfort from them? They won't be babies for long.

My 23 months old still feed to sleep. I really want her to stop this habit cos I'm afraid of her teeth going bad.
My son is a week from turning 1 and he still takes a bottle at nap time and bedtime. Otherwise he doesn’t want it. It’s a comfort item and a vital part of our routine.

There’s the camp who believe in feeding to sleep due to it being “biologically normal.” Then there’s the other camp (that I identify with) who break sleep crutches in order to promote healthy, age-appropriate
sleep in order for momma to be her best emotionally and mentally which in turn leads to a happier baby. Speaking personally, I’m not my best when I’m not sleeping. And when I’m not my best, neither is my baby. Some women can function fine without sleep though. It just depends on you.

[NAME REDACTED] yea two different camps and by saying your camp promotes healthy, age-appropriate
sleep makes it seem like the other camps kids are not healthy and behaving age-appropriate
. I’m 38 and my mom put me to sleep on my own and now days I need a dark room, sound machine, freezing cold temps, etc. Soooo … it’s all a wild guess

[NAME REDACTED] Oh, I didn’t mean for it to come across as babies who are fed to sleep are not healthy or behaving age-appropriate
. What I meant was feeding to sleep can cause babies to depend on feeding in order to fall asleep which can cause increased night wakings and disrupted sleep for their age. Not that they are unhealthy by any means. And if someone is okay with that disrupted sleep then more power to them. Like I said, I personally already have mental health issues and adding no sleep to that would not make me the best mother I can be for my children. And as I said, some women can function fine with a lack of sleep and it’s up to the original poster to decide.

[NAME REDACTED] personally I feed my baby to sleep always have and she’s just over a year and I have never had a problem, my baby has always slept three the night even as a newborn. And we are both “healthy, emotionally and mentally and happier”
[NAME REDACTED] you lucked out! That’s awesome
[NAME REDACTED] same!

I fed my baby asleep often and it was just part of the routine that he liked and it never made anything hard for us. Every baby is different.
I’ve also cuddled or layed next to my son until he fell asleep. Favorite part of the day and it’s never been an issue for us. Sometimes it’s 10 min or 45 until he’s asleep doesn’t bother me.
At a year and a couple months i threw away all the bottles cold turkey and he didn’t even notice. I stopped any night feeds by 10 months I should’ve done it sooner but I didn’t mind getting up once.
It’s up to you when to stop doing something your baby will adjust it may be hard for a couple days but they’ll get it babies/kids are really great at that.

Biologically normal. People are weird as hell for making it a bad "habit". Our babies would stay on us and feed throughout the night. Not like back in the day we put them on the other side of the cave for crib time lmao
My baby is 4 months old and is breastfeed to sleep he sleep right through the night since he was born

I have 4 kids and always fed to sleep. I never forced them to use different way of how to fall asleep but later on in their lives they used dummy instead or learnt when I stopped breastfeeding them. In my opinion it’s a natural way for babies until they are mature enough to learn otherwise. I understand there might be parents who want to teach their children to fall asleep in early age (I mean few months old) but I never forced it on my kids and just followed their lead as they are all different and have different preferences and needs. For example my first one has to be rocked to sleep but my 6 months old hates it and sometimes prefers to have a cuddle without boob. He has no dummy. So it really depends on the child too
[NAME REDACTED] Is a dummy a pacifier or like a stuffed animal or blanket? A type of comfort thingy?
[NAME REDACTED] a dummy in the UK is a pacifier
[NAME REDACTED] ohhh ok. Thank you. That makes sense. I was really hoping it was something that I haven’t tried yet.
[NAME REDACTED] i feel you ! My daughter won't take a dummy and won't self soothe. Just wants my boob all the time. It's hard going, but it doesn't last forever!

[NAME REDACTED] sadly it doesn’t last too long. When you say 2-3 years it sounds long but it’s not. Before you realize they will go to nursery than primary school and than they are nearly young adults. My 7 yrs old starting to look like young lady and I’m wondering where the time has gone. She was the hardest one. I breastfed her 2 and half years. She was an addict to my boobs. She wouldn’t sleep unless rocked. Interesting was she was the only one who had very bad colic. It was hard and it’s all gone now. She wants to choose what she wants to do , wear. She wants to play on her own. She is nearly grown up and I still want to cuddle her to sleep in my bed ♥️😊😅💔
They need to learn to fall asleep on their own so that when they wake up in the night, they can self-soothe.
Yes, it was the source of most of our sleep issues. Fixing that had our baby sleeping through the night and napping very well.
[NAME REDACTED] how did you fix that!!
[NAME REDACTED] By feeding do you mean bottle feeding or even breastfeeding? I breastfeed to sleep. Is that also a problem?

[NAME REDACTED] By creating "hunger pressure". Start feeding your baby 15-20 mintues after a wake up. Stop feeding a minimum of 30 minutes before naps and bedtime. Encourage active feeds (avoid just chewing or playing with the bottle). Feed in well lit spaces and don't encourage sleepiness while feeding.

By 6 months old your baby doesn't need to eat overnight. When your baby wakes at night for a feed it's more out of habit than true hunger. If you can hold fast for even one night and avoid overnight feeding, by the morning they will be ready to eat early in the wake period - breaking that feed to sleep cycle.

Your baby may fuss a little but I promise they will be so much happier when you break this habit and let them learn to connect sleep cycles without the need for milk. I make exceptions to all this for traveling, illness etc. so do what feels right for you and your LO.

[NAME REDACTED] Any kind of feeding to sleep (breast or bottle) has the same effect. I don't think there is anything wrong with it early on with a newborn but eventually you want to stop. It teaches the baby that they need your help to fall asleep instead of teaching them they can fall asleep and connect sleep cycles on their own. I think it's important to make exceptions when your baby needs it, but in general sleeping is a skill that once learned makes your LO much happier.
[NAME REDACTED][NAME REDACTED] Thank you.
6 month old son does for naps usually not so much for bedtime though unless he just exhausted

I would say from my own personal experience.. yes. I wish I’d never followed this advice that was given from the health visitor😔
My son wouldn’t go to sleep without the boob and was a lot more difficult when others are looking after him - for example nap times during the day at nursery & when my partner is trying to get him to sleep in the evenings.

Yes it's a bad habit and everyone says they will grow out of it but in some cases dont...I know plenty of toddler that they keep waking up in the middle of the night for milk even if is cows milk but they need the comfort of it in the middle of the night.

Not necessarily a bad habit, but feeding to sleep could prevent them from getting a “full feed” in and waking up earlier than they would if they had the bottle earlier. Also associates sleeping with food so that could be hard to break

I think it depends. When they are really young infants no, but once they get older it can become a bad habit and it’s worse when they get teeth. Once they start getting teeth you need to brush their teeth after their bottle before bed or the sugar in milk will rot their teeth.

It can be if your baby is waking up multiple times and needing to feed to go back to sleep but some babies will feed to sleep and sleep all night or wake when hungry. I think it depends on the baby personally!
I always fed to sleep, and gradually cut down when I started back at work and started introducing the bottle, now he’s one on weds and I put him to bed awake and he goes to sleep on his own x

Yes. It’s probably ok for a while when baby is little, but eventually it will form sleep association and baby won’t fall asleep without feeding. You can feed the baby before the night, but make sure he/she is not falling asleep on your boob or bottle. After feeding, make sure they are awake before going in bed. That rule applies for rocking, holding etc.
It’s fine until they can start soothing themselves which is about 5-6 months. My daughter would wake up every 2 hours to breastfeed not for hunger but for soothing. It becomes overwhelming. 😅

Here is great book that helped me out
The No-Cry Sleep Solution: Gentle Ways to Help Your Baby Sleep Through the Night https://a.co/d/
g8psZ6q

[NAME REDACTED] Honestly I do how they say “put them down drowsy but awake “ to sleep. And yes there will be some crying involved. Sometimes she falls asleep right away sometimes she cries. Then I make sure she is not hungry.
And keep practicing. My daughter wouldn’t not fall asleep without boob or pacifier now she falls asleep on her own.

But we normally give him a bottle and he’s out and he will let us put him down (only for bedtime not naps!) but I’m trying to slow down the comfort feeding at night bc his teeth feel like they’re about to pop through and I’m nervous about teeth rot

It depends. If your baby then needs feeding to sleep every time, ie throughout the night then it might become a problem

The main concern is when they get teeth, then it causes cavities from the sugar in the milk/formula. Other than that I think it’s just a matter of what works for you and your baby; you can try both ways for a while and see if your baby sleeps better through the night with and without feeding to sleep. No judgment ❤️ My baby still feeds to sleep, and I have no idea how to change it 😂

I think from all of the comments you can gather that every babe is different with different needs and wants. You can either follow your child’s lead or force yours on them. I’m also not sure why they have been coined as ‘bad habits’ as another mom once said that she feels it’s a super power like you have the power to put your babe to sleep by feeding and holding them. ❤️ plus I don’t know of any adult that needs their parents help to sleep or needs a drink in the middle of the night etc.
My first child I nursed to sleep and he was up to sleeping 6 hours by 2 months. With every needle he got, his sleep suffered drastically as in he’d wake up every 2-3 hours and it would take the entire 2 months to get back up to a similar sleep time so at 4 months he just got back to 5 hour stretches but after his 6 month needle he was sleeping the night by 9/10 months. I dried up at 13 months and he quit nursing with zero fuss. My second child would wake 4-6 times a night until I weaned him at 2.5 years old and it wasn’t terribly hard to wean him. I told him mommy doesn’t have any milk (as I’m pretty sure I dried up maybe 1 to 2 months prior) and that my nipples were very sore(I was pregnant again and they hurt to have him nurse) I just did it gradually starting with the first night feed and held him telling him I knew he was sad to not be nursing and it was ok to be sad, he is ok, I love him, etc. i would only cave and nurse him when he got to the really upset cry. We cosleep (or did-he sleeps well in his own bed now at 3) but it worked. Didn’t take too long either. He does still occasionally wakes a time or two at night but I’ll take an occasional wake over 4-6 times. Though my new babe (8 months old) sometimes wakes quite often too but I like to think it’s leaps and teething and growth spurts as some nights are great. I nurse her to sleep and we cosleep too. She doesn’t always want to nurse to sleep either, the odd time I have to rock her or let her fuss for a few minutes before she will sleep/nurse to sleep which was unusual for me since my first two nurses to sleep so easily I feel. I don’t mind though as they are only little for so long. My oldest is still a great sleeper at 8.
If your baby is wanting a bottle, give it to them.

[NAME REDACTED] definitely depends on the child, my daughter is now one never done any sleep training and not even tried weaning yet and shes started to go to sleep on her without me having to feed her now even though I have always fed her to sleep and never denied her of that but she doesn't need it as much anymore, she also has an amazing appetite for food and juice....basica
lly anything I eat she wants 😂 she has started to slowly cut down on being breastfed on her own. Been stress free for me rather than trying to force anything, maybe I've been rather lucky I don't know but I my little girl is proof that this theory does not apply to all babies. My personal opinion but the pressure on mum's to have thier babies not dependent on them anymore is so intense and stressful, I've gone with the flow with my little girl and not had a tough time. Mum's need to be encouraged to be patient and nurturing, not to condition their children so young to so strict routine.

[NAME REDACTED] hey dear she might have silent reflux.. alot of babies get reflux after their 6 months . Arching the back is a way to press the stomach muscles in order to prevent acid from flowing to their throats.. and resisting laying down is also a sign.. you need to decrease a bit her breastfeeding make sure you are burping her again.. keep her back straight even when she is breastfeeding..
when you need to put her in her bed lay her on her left side while using a reflux pillow or put 2 pillows under her shoulders do she will be at 45° pat her back until she falls asleep . If she wakes up again just keep on patting and shushing

[NAME REDACTED] yes that's 100% true.. babies has different personalities, usually all sleep training are for alert types baby and hyper active kids, and that's why there is no 1 rule that fits all. But 95% of babies tend to get sleep crutch associated to breastfeeding..
there are babies who are natural sleepers and they fall asleep anywhere at anytime as if they are programmed to sleep since day 1. God bess your little girl 🥰
Whatever works for you. If it works for you it's not bad.

Depends. Sleep consultant here. If feeding to sleep is working for you and your baby then you can continue it but if it’s causing sleep issues like short naps or multiple wakings at night then you may want to think about dropping it. Happy to chat if you want more info.
